normalised: Lights, Camera, FESTIVAL! Why Film Fests are More Than Just Red Carpets

unnormalised: ## Lights, Camera, FESTIVAL! Why Film Fests are More Than Just Red Carpets
normalised: Hey Bollywood buffs and cinephiles! Ever wondered what goes on behind those glamorous red carpet photos at film festivals? It's way more than just fancy dresses and star spotting, trust me. It's a whole vibe, a celebration of storytelling on the big screen.

unnormalised: Hey Bollywood buffs and cinephiles! Ever wondered what goes on behind those glamorous red carpet photos at film festivals? It's WAY more than just fancy dresses and star spotting, trust me. It's a whole vibe, a celebration of storytelling on the big screen.
normalised: I recently attended the J-i-o M-A-M-I Mumbai Film Festival (missed the two thousand twenty two thousand twenty one edition, thanks C-O-V-I-D!) and it was a total blast. Forget your usual multiplex experience. Here, you get exposed to films you'd probably never see otherwise – independent flicks from Assam, documentaries about rural life in Rajasthan, experimental shorts from film students at F-T-I-I, Pune. Talk about broadening your horizons!

unnormalised: I recently attended the Jio MAMI Mumbai Film Festival (missed the 2020-2021 edition, thanks COVID!) and it was a total blast. Forget your usual multiplex experience. Here, you get exposed to films you'd probably never see otherwise – independent flicks from Assam, documentaries about rural life in Rajasthan, experimental shorts from film students at FTII, Pune. Talk about broadening your horizons!
normalised: Film festivals are also huge for networking. Aspiring filmmakers get to rub shoulders with established directors, producers, and distributors. Imagine getting feedback on your short film from someone who's worked on a Sanjay Leela Bhansali movie! That's the kind of opportunity these fests offer. Plus, there are workshops, Q-and-A sessions with directors, and after-parties where you can chat with fellow film fanatics over some chai and samosas.

normalised: But honestly, the best part is discovering hidden gems. You might stumble upon a low-budget indie film that completely blows your mind, or a documentary that changes your perspective on the world. This year, I saw a film about a small village struggling with water scarcity, and it was incredibly moving. It had zero Bollywood glamour, but it packed a serious emotional punch.

normalised: Don't get me wrong, the red carpets are fun, and seeing stars like Deepika Padukone is definitely a perk! But film festivals are ultimately about the films themselves, the stories they tell, and the conversations they spark. So, next time a film festival rolls into town, ditch the usual Friday night movie and explore something new. You might just find your new favorite filmmaker, or even your next big inspiration! You might have to travel five hundred kilometer, spend rupees five thousand, and take two days off work, but trust me, it's worth it!
